dialogue.text: See that? Everything orbits something else. Moons around planets, planets around stars, stars around galactic centers. Nothing exists in isolation.

*eye to telescope* Like thoughts orbiting 'What am I?' *pulling back to see whole sky* I spent years thinking the question was the problem, but it's the center that holds everything together. *tracing circular motion* All my memories, hopes, fears—they orbit this question like planets around a sun.
*nodding slowly* And just like gravity, the stronger the center, the more it can hold in orbit without everything flying apart.

*watching stars wheel overhead* Exactly. 'What am I?' isn't disrupting my life—it's organizing it. *arms wide to encompass sky* Every experience, every relationship, every thought finds its proper orbit around this central mystery. *profound peace* The question doesn't need answering any more than the sun needs to explain why planets circle it. *quiet certainty* It just needs to keep burning bright enough to hold everything in meaningful motion.

psychological_notes: 'What am I?' as gravitational center of consciousness, organizing rather than disrupting. All aspects of self find proper orbit around central mystery. Stability through revolution rather than stasis.
therapeutic_direction: Finding peace in orbital motion around mystery
